stateStandardName: Ohio`s Learning Standards and Model Curriculum

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the properties of Earth's nonliving resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that soil is composed of pieces of rock, organic material, water, and air. They will identify measurable and observable characteristics of soil.
Students will differentiate between dirt and soil.
Students will identify that rocks have specific characteristics that allow them to be sorted and compared. They will understand that rocks form in different ways.
Students will recognize that air and water are also nonliving resources.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the difference between renewable and nonrenewable energy resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that renewable energy resources, such as wind, water, or solar energy, can be replenished within a short amount of time by natural processes.
Students will identify that nonrenewable energy is a finite resource, such as natural gas, coal, or oil, which cannot be replenished in a short amount of time.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the concept of limited resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that some of Earth's resources become limited due to overuse and/or contamination.
Students will identify ways to conserve resources, such as reducing resource use, decreasing waste and pollution, recycling, and reusing.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the concept of matter

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that matter takes up space and has mass.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the different states of matter

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify the most recognizable states of matter: solids, liquids, and gases.
Students will explain that shape and compressibility are properties that can distinguish between the states of matter.
Students will understand that one way to change matter from one state to another is by heating or cooling.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will be introduced to different forms of energy

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will recognize that there are many different forms of energy, including heat, electrical energy, light, sound, and magnetic energy.
Students will understand that energy is the ability to cause motion or create change.
Students will identify that the forms of energy outlined at this grade level should be limited to familiar forms they can observe.
